and some baking powder now you can sift
that flour baking powder mixture if you
want or you can just whisk it up
same difference and at this point I
realized oh yeah there's sugar in it too
so I threw some sugar in then we're
going to cut it in with our pastry
cutter our pastry blender some ice cold
butter if you only remember two things
from this video those two things are
always keep your butter in the freezer
before you cut it in the flour and when
playing blackjack always split eights I

consistency of coarse crumbs see that
close up for you
alright coarse crumbs stop that's
perfect
we're going to pour in our liquid
ingredients which is milk and sour cream
I'm going to dump in some currants by
the way you're going to read on a blog
why I added the currants at that point
and not at the end like many recipes
call for anyway take the tip of a fork
and stir that together the only way to
screw up a recipe like this is to
overmix it so as soon as it comes
together stop there's going to be some
spots that are a little damp there's
going to be some spots or a little dry
that's fine by the way you can just
spoon this right onto a sheet pan and go
for kind of a round craggily irregular
shape which is a very common way to do
it in the scone making community but I'm
going to go kind of with a biscuit
approach here I'm going to transfer the
mixture onto a floured board so I'm
going to flatten that out into a kind of
a square shape whenever you work with
these kind of dough's biscuit dough
scone dough's make sure you have flour
on your fingers flour on the board but
only enough to keep it from sticking not
too much flour I'm going to give it the
tri-fold I usually do with a biscuit
dough which I think helps the texture
although like many of my theories I
can't prove it once I have it flattened
out into a rectangle I'm going to cut it
into 8 square
for me was about three quarters of an
inch thick you can make them thicker if
you want and you know what I got to be
honest another reason I made these into
squares I was going to build this little
scone henge but I did anyway I'm going
to throw it on a silicon lined baking
sheet I'm going to give it an egg wash
which is just one beaten egg with a tiny
splash of milk a little bit of white
sugar on top that's going to go in a 400
degree oven for about 15 minutes depends
on the size until they're golden brown
make sure you let them cool a little bit
before tearing into him so I left him on
a tray for a minute transfer them onto a
cooling rack let them cool to just warm
and like I said I hadn't made these
before so I was kind of nervous or you
know as nervous as you can get making
scones but when I broke into that thing
it was perfect I don't really eat scones
but I think they were perfect very
tender very moist really really
delicious so for whatever reason I've
had a bunch of scone requests lately so
I thought I'd give it a whirl
and I was very happy with how these came
out these are fantastic served with any
kind of jam or marmalade and of course
clotted cream having said that I've
never had clotted cream nor do I know
what it is but anyway it is really
fantastic with clotted cream so give it
a try by the way make sure you check the
post I'm gonna have some links to some

ingredients are critical make sure you
